This week, I joined my colleagues in co-sponsoring H.R. 14, the John R. Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act. Today marks #WorldDiabetesDay , a day that honors the contributions of Sir Frederick Banting, one of the pioneers who discovered insulin in 1921. 

Back in 1923, when insulin was patented, Banting and his fellow researchers made a groundbreaking decision. They declined to put their names on the patent and sold it to the University of Toronto for just $1. Their perspective was clear: it was unethical for a doctor to profit from a life-saving discovery, and they wanted to ensure that everyone who needed insulin could afford it.

Fast forward over a century, and it’s clear that Banting and his colleagues would be dismayed to witness how their life-saving medication has become synonymous with pharmaceutical price gouging. Stories of individuals with diabetes forced to ration their insulin—sometimes with fatal consequences—are all too common. This is a moral outrage.

Now, more than ever, it’s crucial to safeguard the Inflation Reduction Act, which enables Medicare to negotiate directly with drug manufacturers and caps insulin prices at $35 for Medicare recipients. We must stand firm against any efforts to roll back these essential protections. Together, we can ensure that life-saving medications remain accessible for all.

During WWII, in the late fall of 1944, with Paris secure and ultimate victory inevitable, a football game was organized for Christmas Day. The 101st Airborne Division paratroopers, who had already seen hard fighting in Normandy and the Netherlands, planned what they named the Champagne Bowl. The big game was set to take place on December 25, 1944. When the Battle of the Bulge broke out, the soldiers had to drop everything and march to the Ardennes, abandoning what would become known as The Game That Never Happened.

These “Remembrance” games serve to remind us of those young soldiers that never had a chance to play their game, and instead went off to one of the deadliest campaigns of WWII.
